**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, custody and visitation orders “may be modified if the Court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.”

**G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20**.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28** (for married parties) and/or **G.L. c. 209C, § 20** (for unmarried parents), which authorize the Probate and Family Court to modify custody and visitation orders when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation, travel burdens, and changes in a parent’s circumstances that affect the child’s welfare constitute grounds for modification.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns an initial divorce and custody judgment in which the trial judge authorized the custodial parent to relocate the children to Greece under the G.L. c. 208, § 30 removal standard; it is not a post‑judgment ‘modification’ case. While the opinion does discuss relocation and travel burdens in determining the children’s best interests, it does so in the context of an initial custody/removal order, not as grounds for modifying an existing order. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition that Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation, travel burdens, and changes in a parent’s circumstances constitute grounds for modification.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin…; Hale v. Hale…)… An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change… [and] the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent….”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation, travel burdens, and changes in a parent’s circumstances that affect the child’s welfare constitute grounds for modification.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case addresses relocation and the best‑interests standard, but it does not hold that relocation, travel burdens, or changed parental circumstances are grounds for modification. Instead, it treats relocation in a joint‑custody context as a removal question under G.L. c. 208, § 30, and evaluates whether the proposed move is in the children’s best interests. The opinion does not state or reiterate a rule that such factors constitute a substantial change in circumstances justifying modification of custody or support orders.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part:
‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgment of divorce]….’ … It is a question for a judge, taking into account all of the facts, whether an increase in travel time between households and schools brought about by removal, and other burdens of distance, will significantly impair either parent’s ability to exercise existing responsibilities, and ultimately whether removal is in a child’s best interests.”

*Williams v. Pitney*, 409 Mass. 449 (199.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation, travel burdens, and changes in a parent’s circumstances that affect the child’s welfare constitute grounds for modification.
*Williams v. Pitney*, 409 Mass. 449 (199.support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision, but it is not a modification case premised on relocation or travel burdens as grounds for changing custody or support. The opinion addresses what standard applies when a parent seeks to relocate children out of Massachusetts despite a surviving separation agreement, and holds that G.L. c. 208, § 30 and the Yannas ‘real advantage’ standard control. It does not discuss or hold that relocation, travel burdens, or changes in a parent’s circumstances are grounds for modification in the general sense asserted by the proposition.
*Williams v. Pitney*, 409 Mass. 449 (199.relevant_excerpt: “We must decide what standard the judge should apply to determine whether to grant a request for the removal of children from the Commonwealth: the c. 208, § 30, ‘real advantage’ standard, the ‘countervailing equities’ standard, or some other standard. The statute is controlling over the provision contracted by the parties. Therefore, the statutory standard is to be used, even in this case, where the parties have contracted for consent of the other before removal.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation, travel burdens, and changes in a parent’s circumstances that affect the child’s welfare constitute grounds for modification.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely rejects the idea that a custodial parent’s relocation, by itself, is a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification of custody. The court holds that a modification must be based on changes other than the move and reverses a custody change that was predicated on relocation and related temporary orders. Thus, rather than treating relocation and its burdens as grounds for modification, the case treats them as insufficient and improper bases for custody modification.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 … The custody claim must be considered in light of established principles governing custody determinations.”

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation, travel burdens, and changes in a parent’s circumstances that affect the child’s welfare constitute grounds for modification.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and Yannas, not a modification case turning on relocation or travel burdens as grounds for modification. Although it discusses travel burdens, distance, and changes arising from remarriage in assessing removal and best interests, it does not stand for a general rule that such factors themselves constitute grounds for modification of custody or parenting plans. Its brief discussion of G.L. c. 208, § 28 only clarifies that remarriage can be a post‑judgment ‘material and substantial change,’ not that relocation or travel burdens per se are repeatedly recognized grounds for modification.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28… Changed circumstances are those that occur subsequent to the judgment of divorce… In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances occurring subsequent to the date of divorce. The judge’s contrary treatment contributed to his devaluation of the mother’s marriage as a factor to be considered….”

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation, travel burdens, and changes in a parent’s circumstances that affect the child’s welfare constitute grounds for modification.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal and child-support case, not a general modification decision based on relocation, travel burdens, or changed parental circumstances. The court applies the Yannas ‘real advantage/best interests’ removal framework under G.L. c. 208, § 30, and does not hold that relocation or related travel burdens constitute grounds for modification of custody or support; rather, it denies relocation while separately remanding the child-support modification issue for more findings about the new spouse’s contributions. Thus it does not stand for the broad proposition claimed.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: “The mother, Dawn Michelle Murray, appeals from a judgment of the Probate and Family Court dismissing her complaint for modification, which sought to remove the minor children of the marriage to the State of California… Where the parent seeking to move has primary physical custody of the children, the standard governing removal of the minor children from the Commonwealth requires a determination whether there is a real advantage to the custodial parent and consideration of the best interests of the children and the interests of both parents… We… affirm that part of the judgment denying the mother’s request to remove the children to California.”

*J.F. v. D.F.*, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 782 (2.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation, travel burdens, and changes in a parent’s circumstances that affect the child’s welfare constitute grounds for modification.
*J.F. v. D.F.*, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 782 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion is a custody‑modification case, but the asserted grounds for modification are emotional neglect and the child’s preference, not relocation, travel burdens, or changes in the parents’ circumstances like moves or travel difficulties. The court mentions relocation only procedurally (the father’s relocation request was deemed moot once custody was denied) and does not articulate or apply any rule that relocation or travel burdens constitute grounds for modification. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the specific relocation‑based proposition stated.
*J.F. v. D.F.*, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 782 (2.relevant_excerpt: “In view of the decision he reached, the judge determined that the father’s request for ‘relocation relief [was] moot as [the father does] not have any form of physical custody.’ … General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a judge of the Probate and Family Court may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children.’”

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation, travel burdens, and changes in a parent’s circumstances that affect the child’s welfare constitute grounds for modification.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion does address relocation and removal standards under G. L. c. 208, § 30, but it does so in a divorce/removal context, not in a postjudgment modification context, and it does not state that relocation, travel burdens, or changed parental circumstances are grounds for modification. Instead, the court vacates the open‑ended removal provision and remands for a new evidentiary hearing, reiterating the Yannas real‑advantage/best‑interests framework. It neither discusses modification standards nor characterizes relocation or travel burdens as a basis for modifying an existing judgment, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “A request for removal is governed by G. L. c. 208, § 30, which states that … [a] minor child … shall not … be removed out of this Commonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders. … The statutory standard of ‘upon cause shown’ means that removal must be in the best interests of the child. Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985). In Yannas, the court held that the judge must determine whether the proposed move represents a ‘real advantage’ to the custodial parent.”}

*Macri v. Macri*, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 362.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation, travel burdens, and changes in a parent’s circumstances that affect the child’s welfare constitute grounds for modification.

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation, travel burdens, and changes in a parent’s circumstances that affect the child’s welfare constitute grounds for modification.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rolde v. Rolde is a divorce, custody, property division, and visitation case. It does not involve a post-judgment modification proceeding, nor does it discuss relocation, travel burdens, or changed parental circumstances as grounds for modifying an existing custody or support order. The court’s analysis centers on best interests of the children for an initial custody determination and permissible scope of property division and visitation, so it does not provide authority for the stated modification/relocation proposition.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings… On this record we cannot say that the judge was clearly wrong in awarding sole custody to the wife.”
